p: Of the four billion species that have evolved on Earth over the past 3.5 billion years, 99% are considered to have disappeared ( Novacek, 2001), most notably in the ‘Big Five’ mass extinctions ( Raup & Sepkoski, 1982; Jablonski & Chaloner, 1994; Bambach, 2006). Considerable species losses over the past few centuries and millennia as a result of anthropogenic climate change have sounded the alarm about a possible sixth mass extinction ( Barnosky et al., 2011). Effective conservation planning is necessary to avoid potential biodiversity loss, and an understanding of the distribution dynamics of organisms in response to climate change underlies the development of effective conservation strategies ( Razgour et al., 2013).
